on what makes conduct and great what
makes even what makes conducting work
essentially what conducting is about is
getting players to play their best and
to be able to use their energy to access
their point of view about the music
there is a connection between the
gesture the physical presence the aura
that a conductor can project and what

things that I'm thinking at the

the strings are playing this unusual
strident tremolo in fortissimo with an

I said that there should be something
incongruous and irritating about that it
should doesn't fit with what seems to be

reflection and and the beauty of the the
chorale
I give an upbeat for everybody I try to
breathe really well I'm thinking a
couple of beats ahead like three four
and then while I'm giving this I'm also
adding a little something that happens
at the same time so after the strings
give their accent I'm actually only
thinking at that point of the
continuation of the chorale sound an
accent is a an instantaneous or it's a
momentary event what happens after that
is that the wins have to continue to
sustain and sing through this is
counterpoint there are their lines that
that exist together and relate to each

a basic flow that happens but one thing
I was particularly thinking about just
now was bringing out different layers so
when one instrument for example has a
moving line that is not simultaneous
with something else
I was specifically trying to make
contact with the bassoon player and let
him know that I think something
important is coming up and then share
that contour as it happened I find that
interesting so it's not just a it's not
just a monolithic homogenized texture
it's it's a texture that hopefully works
well together but has local features
based on how each individual mood line
moves
the way you let go of a note the shape
of the tail of the note if you will has

together so if one person is finishing a

slight curved tapering or bored with an

think about that to make that a goal one
thing that I changed I tried anyway to
change in my conducting was the way I

longer duration and that actually is
what makes a piece like this this
chorale chorale interesting because it
is mostly about lungs it's not about
figuration or technique or or rhythmic
patterns
I try to prepare the arrivals from long
before they come and probably longer
before the arrivals come than anyone
would necessarily think it's already a
goal in my mind just sort of where we're
going harmonically how long it's going
to take to settle down to to earth and
over the course of the piece each one is
more and more settled dynamically it's
very clear it starts out at one level in
each successive arrival each successive
phrase is softer and the last until
finally you're at a very very peaceful
unbelievably calm place
a lot of people have said this I know
but but there are some conductors who

together and physically all in order
that doesn't necessarily mean that

is to make it really obvious that you're

that's not actually conducting that's

you're interested and you're following
